meanings.definition: A comparative form of 'fain', meaning more willing or eager.
meanings.sent1: She was the fainer of the two to help with the project.
meanings.sent2: He always seemed the fainer to try new things.
meanings.sent3: The cat was fainer to play with the yarn than the ball.
meanings.sent4: The sun was fainer to shine on the flowers than the rocks.
meanings.sent5: The child's eyes were fainer with excitement as the birthday party approached.

meanings.sent1: He would often fainer illness to avoid going to school.
meanings.sent2: She had to fainer interest in the boring conversation.
meanings.sent3: The actor had to fainer surprise when the cake exploded on set.
meanings.sent4: The magician could fainer magic with his tricks.
meanings.sent5: The spy had to fainer ignorance about the secret mission.
